Award.AwardTitle: P2C2: Collaborative Research: Dust Deposition, Paleo-Export Production, and Migration of the (ITCZ) Through the Last Glacial Cycle in the West-Central Pacific (Line Islands)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project's goal is to examine variations in dust deposition throughout the last 150,000 years in the west-central Pacific from a suite of ocean sediment cores recently recovered from the Line Islands Ridge and constituting a roughly north-south transect across the modern Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) near 160Â°W longitude.

During the interval of interest for the project, the Earth's climate shifted from full glaciation to one of the warmest interglacials in the last million years. Following that peak interglacial, global climate varied through multiple 20,000 year cycles while trending toward a return to full glacial conditions at the last glacial maximum (LGM) before the last deglaciation and Holocene interglacial.

Windblown dust plays important roles in influencing and recording climate. In the atmosphere, dust contributes to the planetary albedo and serves as cloud condensation nuclei. In the ocean, dust may fertilize biological productivity through the addition of crucial trace nutrients, and provide ballast for the sinking of particles, thus enhancing carbon export from the surface ocean and drawing down atmospheric carbon dioxide. In deep-sea sediments, the amount, location and type of dust deposition provide clues for reconstructing its past sources, pathways, magnitude and removal processes. These removal processes include the shifting rain belts of the ITCZ that follows the thermal equator over the tropical ocean.

The project will advance understanding of natural variations in climate, dust, productivity, and the hydrological cycle, and will promote training and learning for several early career scientists as well as undergraduate students. The research team will also leverage their research and education efforts in collaboration with middle school and high school science teachers through the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory's Earth2Class program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This was a collaborative project that sought to explore past variations in dust deposition, biological productivity and north-to-south migration of the rain belts associated with the inter-tropical convergence zone in the central equatorial Pacific Ocean. We used a set of recently acquired deep-sea sediment cores taken at different latitudes near the Line Islands chain in order to explore these variations through several past ice ages and intervening warm intervals and combined these with more widely distributed existing sediment cores. Our colleagues at Texas A&M University (TAMU) led the portion of the study that focused on tracking wind patterns through geochemical identification of the dust sources in Asia and the Americas, and we at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory of Columbia University (LDEO) led the studies of dust deposition, paleo-productivity and changes in deep ocean chemistry.

 The sediments of four of the Line Island study cores and several others were analyzed for bulk sediment composition, and to determine the naturally occurring abundance in the sediments of a suite of isotopes of several elements, including uranium, thorium and protactinium. In addition, we analyzed the abundance of key indicator elements and isotopes in the microfossil shells of single-celled organisms that lived at or near the sea surface. Much of the research was accomplished by junior scientists, including PhD students, undergraduates and a postdoctoral investigator, who all acquired skills and experience that will contribute to their academic and professional development.

 Our findings include evidence that dust deposition from the continents increased at all study sites during each of the last two glaciations. The deposition spiked briefly during several time intervals when global ocean and wind circulation patterns are believed to have shifted, leading to a colder, dryer, windier northern hemisphere. During at least one of these intervals, the tropical rain belts shifted dramatically southward, suggesting that the southern hemisphere did not cool as much as the north and instead appeared to warm up. The evidence also indicates that the deep Pacific Ocean held less dissolved oxygen during each glacial interval, suggesting greater glacial carbon storage at depth, since biological processes dominantly trade off oxygen and carbon in the abyssal ocean. This set of findings formed the thesis chapters of a PhD student supported by the project.

Other of our findings relate to the last glacial interval in particular, and strongly support the idea that the deposition of continental dust was generally higher but that biological productivity was nevertheless lower at the peak of the last ice age nearly everywhere across the entire tropical Pacific Ocean. This was confirmed by multiple indicators and at many locations, thus revealing no evidence of the previously hypothesized iron fertilization by increased continental dust delivery to the surface ocean during glaciations.

In the course of the project, two PhD students completed their thesis work and training, and several undergraduate students were given research experience opportunities. Three project participants, including both PIs and a PhD student, helped lead project-related workshops for high school science teachers in the New York area.
